conclusion: Two pieces of fabric, A and B, are held in the air above blocks C, D, E, and F.
Blocks C and D are under the left fabric A, and blocks E and F are under the right fabric B.
Gravity accelerates both fabrics straight down toward the blocks when supports are removed.
Fabric A touches the taller edges of blocks C and D, stopping its downward motion at those points.
Fabric B touches the top of the taller block F first, then shortly afterward touches block E.
Each cloth continues to sink in any open gaps until the material has nowhere lower to go.
Fabric A drapes over the tops of C and D and forms a sagging valley in the space between them.
Fabric B stretches over the high edge of F, then drapes down to lie on E and spills into the lower area of the table between the two blocks.
Friction and the pinned corners bring both fabrics to rest.
The final shapes show the silhouettes of the underlying blocks: small plateaus where the fabric rests on the block tops, and smooth folds between them.
Fabric A ends up neatly draped over blocks C and D, while fabric B ends up draped over blocks E and F.
All objects come to rest with the fabric conforming to the shapes of the four blocks and the table surface.
